title: 106_hr605
content:
The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court. Retired judges must provide written notice of availability and willingness to be recalled, which is irrevocable. Recall-eligible retired judges are those who have provided such notice. The chief judge may recall a recall-eligible retired judge for up to 90 days per year with written certification. If the retired judge declines to serve, they may be removed from recall eligibility. A recall-eligible retired judge who becomes permanently disabled and unable to perform further service on the court shall be removed from recall eligibility. A recalled retired judge may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled judge varies based on retirement status. Recalled retired judges under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 are considered reemployed annuitants. This section does not affect the right of retired judges to serve as reemployed annuitants. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's service. Fractional years below 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to specify the retired pay of judges based on different circumstances: for recall-eligible retired judges, the pay is determined by their status at retirement or as a chief judge; for judges not available for recall, the pay remains at the retirement rate; and for judges removed from recall status, the pay is adjusted accordingly. The retired pay of judges is determined based on different circumstances: for recall-eligible retired judges, the pay is determined by their status at retirement or as a chief judge; for judges not available for recall, the pay remains at the retirement rate; and for judges removed from recall status, the pay is adjusted accordingly. Cost-of-living adjustments apply to retired pay under specific conditions. The retired pay of judges is adjusted to match the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Military retired pay is suspended during active service as a judge and resumes upon retirement. SEC. 6 introduces a limitation on activities of retired judges regarding representing clients in veterans' benefits claims, leading to a forfeiture of retired pay. SEC. 7 discusses early retirement authority for current judges to ensure staggered terms. Retirement authorization for eligible judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims from 1999 to 2003. Eligibility criteria include 10 years of service, retired pay election, 20 years of service, and minimum age of 55. In case of multiple eligible judges, the most senior judge can retire. Notice must be provided for retirement in a specific year. 
    Eligible judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims must provide written notice to retire by April 1 of the year, or November 1 for retirement in 1999. The retirement date shall be specified and irrevocable. Judges retiring in accordance with this section for 1999 shall do so not earlier than 90 days and not later than 120 days after providing notice. Retired judges from the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims are considered retired under specific provisions of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay is calculated based on years of service and age, with adjustments in retired pay applicable for judges available for recall. The retirement laws apply to recall-eligible retired judges from the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims under specific provisions of title 38, United States Code. Amendments are made to the duty of the actuary regarding the determination of present value for payments from the retirement fund.
